title: What are data-* attributes in HTML?
content: How can they be used to store custom data for JavaScript?
explanation: data-* attributes allow storing custom data on elements, accessible via element.dataset in JS.
sampleAnswers: data-* attributes allow storing custom data on elements, accessible via element.dataset in JS.

title: Explain the difference between <header>, <nav>, and <footer>.
content: Provide semantic meaning and typical use cases.
explanation: <header> contains page or section intro content, <nav> contains links/navigation, <footer> contains metadata, copyright, or contact info.
sampleAnswers: <header> contains page or section intro content, <nav> contains links/navigation, <footer> contains metadata, copyright, or contact info.

title: What is the difference between <summary> and <details>?
content: Provide an example of creating an expandable/collapsible section.
explanation: <details><summary>Click Me</summary>Hidden content here</details> creates an expandable section. <summary> is always used inside <details>.
sampleAnswers: <details><summary>Click Me</summary>Hidden content here</details> creates an expandable section. <summary> is always used inside <details>.

title: Explain the difference between <label> and aria-label.
explanation: <label> associates text with form controls visually and programmatically. aria-label provides an accessible name for elements without visible labels.
sampleAnswers: <label> associates text with form controls visually and programmatically. aria-label provides an accessible name for elements without visible labels.

title: What is the difference between <blockquote> and <q>?
explanation: <blockquote> is for long quotations (block-level), <q> is for short inline quotes.
sampleAnswers: <blockquote> is for long quotations (block-level), <q> is for short inline quotes.

title: How does the defer attribute differ from async on <script>?
content: Explain execution order and DOM interaction.
explanation: defer: script executes after HTML parsing, preserves order. async: executes as soon as downloaded, order not guaranteed.
sampleAnswers: defer: script executes after HTML parsing, preserves order. async: executes as soon as downloaded, order not guaranteed.

title: What is the purpose of the <template> element?
content: Provide an example of using it with JavaScript.
explanation: <template> holds HTML markup that is not rendered initially. Example: const template = document.querySelector('template'); document.body.appendChild(template.content.cloneNode(true));
sampleAnswers: <template> holds HTML markup that is not rendered initially. Example: const template = document.querySelector('template'); document.body.appendChild(template.content.cloneNode(true));

title: Explain the difference between <main> and <article>.
explanation: <main> represents the main content of the page. <article> is a self-contained piece of content, like a blog post.
sampleAnswers: <main> represents the main content of the page. <article> is a self-contained piece of content, like a blog post.

title: What is the difference between <output> and <progress>?
content: Include example of calculating and showing form results.
explanation: <output> shows calculated values or results (e.g., sum of inputs). <progress> shows task completion percentage.
sampleAnswers: <output> shows calculated values or results (e.g., sum of inputs). <progress> shows task completion percentage.

title: How do <source> and <track> differ when used inside <audio>/<video>?
content: Explain how multiple formats and captions/subtitles are handled.
explanation: <source> allows multiple media formats; browser picks supported one. <track> adds captions/subtitles, can be multiple languages.
sampleAnswers: <source> allows multiple media formats; browser picks supported one. <track> adds captions/subtitles, can be multiple languages.

title: Explain the difference between <embed> and <object>.
content: Include practical use cases and browser support considerations.
explanation: <embed> directly embeds external content (Flash, PDF), <object> can embed media with fallback content and is more flexible.
sampleAnswers: <embed> directly embeds external content (Flash, PDF), <object> can embed media with fallback content and is more flexible.

title: What is the difference between <b> and <strong>, and <i> and <em>?
content: Include semantic meaning and accessibility impact.
explanation: <strong> and <em> convey importance and emphasis semantically; <b> and <i> are visual only.
sampleAnswers: <strong> and <em> convey importance and emphasis semantically; <b> and <i> are visual only.

title: Explain how tabindex works and when to use negative values.
content: Include impact on keyboard navigation and accessibility.
explanation: tabindex='0' allows normal focus order, tabindex='-1' removes element from tab order but still focusable programmatically.
sampleAnswers: tabindex='0' allows normal focus order, tabindex='-1' removes element from tab order but still focusable programmatically.

title: What is the difference between <area> and <map>?
content: Provide an example for creating image maps.
explanation: <map> defines the image map container; <area> defines clickable regions with href, coords, and shape attributes.
sampleAnswers: <map> defines the image map container; <area> defines clickable regions with href, coords, and shape attributes.

title: Explain the difference between <meta name='viewport'> and CSS media queries.
content: When and why are both needed for responsive design?
explanation: meta viewport sets the initial scaling and width for mobile devices; media queries adjust layout/styles based on device size. Both together enable responsive design.
sampleAnswers: meta viewport sets the initial scaling and width for mobile devices; media queries adjust layout/styles based on device size. Both together enable responsive design.
